title: Florida alligator sanctuary owner catches loose gator in Magnolia Lake while visiting family in Pennsylvania
description: Gator sanctuary owner Kyle Asplundh says he wrangled an alligator found in Magnolia Lake in Bristol Township.
content:
Man who runs Florida gator sanctuary captures an alligator while visiting family in Pennsylvania

Man who runs Florida gator sanctuary captures an alligator while visiting family in Pennsylvania

Man who runs Florida gator sanctuary captures an alligator while visiting family in Pennsylvania

After warnings about a gator spotted in a Bucks County lake, a Florida alligator sanctuary owner sprang into action and wrangled the reptile.

Now a Florida resident, Kyle Asplundh was in Bucks County visiting family when he decided to drive over to Magnolia Lake in Bristol Township to catch the 3-and-a-half-foot male.

Asplundh told CBS News Philadelphia he went while it was dark out, because that would make it easier to see the gator's eyes.

"I snuck in the water, and tried to do what I've done many times before. Unfortunately, at that point, the gator was pretty wary of individuals. I got pretty close, but the gator took off into the lily pads," Asplundh said.

At that point, he left and bought a headlamp before returning to the lake.

"Then I snuck into the lily pads after him," Asplundh said. That second attempt turned out to be a success.

He is set to meet with wildlife officials on Friday and is hoping for clearance to take the gator to his sanctuary.

On Thursday, Bristol Township police warned residents to stay out of the lake and the nearby Mill Creek until the Pennsylvania Game Commission could deal with the gator. That was before Asplundh got involved.

This isn't the first Philadelphia-area gator that Asplundh has dealt with. In 2023, an 8-foot alligator named "Big Mack" was found in a Philly rowhome. Asplundh says he brought Big Mack back to his sanctuary and he's doing well.

Asplundh says families often buy gators as pets but abandon them once they become too big.

We'll follow up to see what's next for this gator.
summary: Florida resident Kyle Asplundh, the owner of Florida gator sanctuary, was visiting family in Pennsylvania when he caught a loose gator in Magnolia Lake in Bristol Township, while he was out visiting family. He drove to the lake to catch the 3-and-a-half-foot male alligator, which he believes was a 3-year-old male. Asplondh said he went while it was dark out to capture the animal, but it took him a second attempt. He is currently meeting with wildlife officials to secure clearance to take the animal to his sanctuary. This isn't the first time Asplundoh has encountered a Philadelphia-area gator; in 2023, an 8-foot alligator named "Big Mack" was found in a Philly rowhome and is reportedly doing well.
shortSummary: A Florida alligator sanctuary owner, Kyle Asplundh, captured a 3-and-a-half-foot alligator in Magnolia Lake in Pennsylvania while visiting family, leading to a successful capture attempt.

ACCT Philly removes 8-foot alligator "Big Mack" from home
PHILADELPHIA (CBS) -- An 8-foot alligator named Big Mack was rescued from a North Philadelphia row home by ACCT Philly. Big Mack is the Philadelphia animal shelter's third gator rescued just this month.
This is the day when North Philadelphia resident Yali says "See ya later, alligator," literally.
"My husband had him since 2011," Yali said. "We've had him all these years, been in the basement."
Locked in this makeshift enclosure, this alligator used to be little, but it grew to 8 feet, 127 pounds, and now that Yali and her soon-to-be ex-husband have grown apart.
"I wanted him out of here," Yali said.
So she called ACCT Philly to find Big Mack a new home.
After wrestling Big Mack out of his enclosure, animal protection officers began to tie him up and remove him from the basement. It took three people to carry Big Mack.
"Hopefully, you find a nice home for him," Yali said.
Big Mack's home, for now, is ACCT Philly's shelter.
This is the third alligator the shelter's taken in just this month.
Executive director Sarah Barnett says Big Mack was supposed to go to a sanctuary in Michigan, but he's too large for the plane they secured. They're now looking at local options.
"We're going to find placement for him," Barnett said. "That's going to give him the space and the care that he needs."
And allowing ACCT Philly to eventually say, "See ya later alligator."
It is illegal in Philadelphia to own an exotic animal with a propensity to be dangerous, but ACCT Philly says it won't pursue any criminal charges. They say they'd rather people reach out for assistance instead of being punished.

argos_summary: Kyle Asplundh, who operates a gator sanctuary in Florida, captured a 3-and-a-half-foot alligator in Pennsylvania while visiting family, after it was spotted in a local lake. He successfully wrangled the gator after two attempts and plans to take it to his sanctuary pending clearance from wildlife officials. This incident follows Asplundh's previous involvement with another alligator, 'Big Mack,' which was rescued from a Philadelphia home.
